title: Sudden Decrease in Speech Understanding with Asymmetric SNHL
chief_complaint: I don't feel like I'm hearing as well as I used to. I'm not sure if my hearing aids are malfunctioning or if my hearing has actually changed.

problem_summary.onset: Recent change noticed after 2 years of successful hearing aid use.
problem_summary.laterality: Bilateral, but Right ear is reported as worse.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Reduced benefit from current hearing aids.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Determine if equipment is broken or if hearing has changed.

history.present_illness: Patient reports successful bilateral hearing aid use for the past 2 years. Recently feels she is not hearing as well as previously. Unsure if cause is device or physiological.
history.otologic_history: Right ear historically slightly worse than left. Long-standing tinnitus reported. Denies dizziness, otalgia, aural pressure, or fullness.
history.noise_exposure_history: No reported history of loud noise exposure.
history.prior_management: Bilateral hearing aids for 2 years. Previous hearing tests available for comparison.
history.patient_goals: Check hearing aids and hearing status.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear: Normal to slight SNHL (250-1k Hz), steeply sloping to severe (3k-8k Hz). Left ear: Normal to slight SNHL (250-2k Hz), sloping to severe (3k-8k Hz). Comparison to prior tests shows a slight decrease at 2000 and 3000 Hz in the Right ear.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: SRT aligns with PTA. Significant asymmetry in Word Recognition Scores (WRS). Right ear WRS is poor (52-56%) and has dropped significantly from a previous score of 88%. Left ear WRS remains good (86%).

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Reflexes present at 500 and 1000 Hz; absent at 2000 and 4000 Hz (ipsi and contra). Reflex decay negative at 500 and 1000 Hz.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with bilateral sloping sensorineural hearing loss, with the right ear exhibiting slightly poorer thresholds in the mid-to-high frequencies compared to the left. Most notably, there is a significant asymmetry in speech understanding; the right ear Word Recognition Score (WRS) has deteriorated to ~52-56% compared to a prior baseline of 88%, while the left ear remains stable at 86%. Peripheral middle ear function is normal.
counseling_points: Your hearing test confirms that your hearing aids are not malfunctioning; rather, there has been a change in your right ear's hearing ability.
While the change in hearing levels (beeps) is slight, there is a significant drop in your right ear's ability to understand words clearly.
Because of this asymmetry and the change in speech understanding, I am referring you to an ENT specialist for further evaluation to rule out any medical causes beyond the inner ear.
The ENT may recommend an ABR test or imaging to investigate the nerve pathway.
notes_for_actor: You are not in pain or dizzy, just frustrated that you can't hear as well as you did two years ago.
You initially assume the hearing aids are broken. You should appear concerned when told the aids are fine but your ear has changed medically.
You have had ringing (tinnitus) in your ears for a long time.
